update.description: The overall goal for this work is to enable users to create an assembly of models. As opposed to using the `<include>` element which just copies the links from one model to another and prefixes the link names with a namespace, the new approach simply allows one to embed a `<model>` element inside another.
update.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

pullrequest.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

content.raw:
The `copy_data` approach is nice when you don't need to validate the child elements. With nested models it would be nice to support multiple levels of nesting with validation.

I was looking at how [XSD handles recursion](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/148988/recursion-in-xsd-schemas), and we can do something similar.

```
<element name="model" required="*">

    <element ref="model" required="*">
    </element>

</element>
```
content.html:
The copy_data approach is nice when you don't need to validate the child elements. With nested models it would be nice to support multiple levels of nesting with validation.

I was looking at how XSD handles recursion, and we can do something similar.

<element name="model" required="*">

    <element ref="model" required="*">
    </element>

</element>

pullrequest.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

content.raw: I think currently branch `mentor2_v2` supports both partially and fully scoped names. It first tries to get the scoped name, if it fails, it replaces the top level model name with the internal parent model name and tries to get that. That's how it's being possible to insert several vehicles at once in MENTOR2. [This](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/d8633d0d6d8d5d82521962c4b6c4f9e9eef9d79d?at=default) is the relevant commit.
content.html: I think currently branch mentor2_v2 supports both partially and fully scoped names. It first tries to get the scoped name, if it fails, it replaces the top level model name with the internal parent model name and tries to get that. That's how it's being possible to insert several vehicles at once in MENTOR2. This is the relevant commit.

content.raw: I see. Just to confirm, we should support both partially and fully scoped names? If we support partially scoped names only, I guess this means that we make the implicit assumption that we shouldn't allow users to create joints (in SDF) between two top level models in the world.
content.html: I see. Just to confirm, we should support both partially and fully scoped names? If we support partially scoped names only, I guess this means that we make the implicit assumption that we shouldn't allow users to create joints (in SDF) between two top level models in the world.

pull_request.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

pullrequest.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

content.raw:
Here's a complicated but useful idea: partially scoped names.

Example: mobile base with two robot arms and grippers (call it `wall-e`).
The base, arms, and grippers are separate models that are nested into `wall-e`:

~~~
<model name="wall-e">
  <include>
    <uri>model://mobile_base</uri>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_arm</uri>
    <name>left_arm</name>
    <pose>0 -1 0  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_arm</uri>
    <name>right_arm</name>
    <pose>0 1 0  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_gripper</uri>
    <name>left_gripper</name>
    <pose>0 -1 1  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_gripper</uri>
    <name>right_gripper</name>
    <pose>0 1 1  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  ...
</model>
~~~

We'll use joints in order to attach everything together.
The following uses fully scoped names:

~~~
<model name="wall-e">
  ...
  <joint name="left_shoulder" type="revolute">
    <parent>wall-e::mobile_base::link</parent>
    <child>wall-e::left_arm::base_link</child>
  </joint>
  ...
</model>
~~~

This causes a problem if you try to insert two `wall-e` models
into a world file; the `wall-e` name will increment
to `wall-e_0` and break the hard-coded name.

If we allow "partially scoped names",
then the nested model names (`mobile_base`, `left_arm`) could be used
without the parent model name (`wall-e`).

~~~
<model name="wall-e">
  ...
  <joint name="left_shoulder" type="revolute">
    <parent>mobile_base::link</parent>
    <child>left_arm::base_link</child>
  </joint>
</model>
~~~

I think this would be useful, but we should try to identify
the order in which models will be searched for names.
content.html:
Here's a complicated but useful idea: partially scoped names.

Example: mobile base with two robot arms and grippers (call it wall-e). The base, arms, and grippers are separate models that are nested into wall-e:

<model name="wall-e">
  <include>
    <uri>model://mobile_base</uri>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_arm</uri>
    <name>left_arm</name>
    <pose>0 -1 0  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_arm</uri>
    <name>right_arm</name>
    <pose>0 1 0  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_gripper</uri>
    <name>left_gripper</name>
    <pose>0 -1 1  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  <include>
    <uri>model://little_gripper</uri>
    <name>right_gripper</name>
    <pose>0 1 1  0 0 0</pose>
  </include>
  ...
</model>

We'll use joints in order to attach everything together. The following uses fully scoped names:

<model name="wall-e">
  ...
  <joint name="left_shoulder" type="revolute">
    <parent>wall-e::mobile_base::link</parent>
    <child>wall-e::left_arm::base_link</child>
  </joint>
  ...
</model>

This causes a problem if you try to insert two wall-e models into a world file; the wall-e name will increment to wall-e_0 and break the hard-coded name.

If we allow "partially scoped names", then the nested model names (mobile_base, left_arm) could be used without the parent model name (wall-e).

<model name="wall-e">
  ...
  <joint name="left_shoulder" type="revolute">
    <parent>mobile_base::link</parent>
    <child>left_arm::base_link</child>
  </joint>
</model>

I think this would be useful, but we should try to identify the order in which models will be searched for names.

content.raw: No it doesn't need a unique name. To get a unique nested model you'll need to pass in a scoped name as arguments into the `GetModel` function, otherwise it'll return the first nested model it finds with the specified name.
content.html: No it doesn't need a unique name. To get a unique nested model you'll need to pass in a scoped name as arguments into the GetModel function, otherwise it'll return the first nested model it finds with the specified name.

pullrequest.title: Add support for nested models in Gazebo

content.raw:
I think the context menu (`ModelRightMenu`) might also need some tweaking, which will likely introduce some usability issues.  There seems to be quite a few different combinations of functionality which should be available according to the nested model's level. This is just a rough draft of how the functionality could be distributed.

# Top level model

* Move To

* Follow

* ~~Apply Force/Torque~~ - the dialog works with a list of links, so it might become too messy if it has all the links for all nested models? On the other hand, having to select the lowest level model could make it hard to discover.

* Edit model

* View

* Copy/Paste

* Delete

# Intermediate models

* Move To

* Follow

* View

# Lowest level model

* Move To

* Follow

* Apply Force/Torque

* View

# Link

* Move To

* Follow

* Apply Force/Torque
content.html:
I think the context menu (ModelRightMenu) might also need some tweaking, which will likely introduce some usability issues. There seems to be quite a few different combinations of functionality which should be available according to the nested model's level. This is just a rough draft of how the functionality could be distributed.

Top level model

  • Move To

  • Follow

  • Apply Force/Torque - the dialog works with a list of links, so it might become too messy if it has all the links for all nested models? On the other hand, having to select the lowest level model could make it hard to discover.

  • Edit model

  • View

  • Copy/Paste

  • Delete

Intermediate models

  • Move To

  • Follow

  • View

Lowest level model

  • Move To

  • Follow

  • Apply Force/Torque

  • View

Link

  • Move To

  • Follow

  • Apply Force/Torque

content.raw: I think it's a nice idea not to show the nested model's internal structure for now. I think it could be nice to load it differently into the 3D scene as well. Though I'm not sure if it's a nice idea to hide its internal structure (joints, collisons...), since it won't be possible to edit them, or if it's better to leave it there to give the user a notion of the whole model.
content.html: I think it's a nice idea not to show the nested model's internal structure for now. I think it could be nice to load it differently into the 3D scene as well. Though I'm not sure if it's a nice idea to hide its internal structure (joints, collisons...), since it won't be possible to edit them, or if it's better to leave it there to give the user a notion of the whole model.
